awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Performance Computing Cluster for Research and Teaching at Rutgers University-Newark
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to Rutgers University-Newark supports the acquisition and deployment of a High-Performance Computing (HPC) cluster (named PRICE) dedicated to research, teaching and societal outreach efforts. PRICE will have 60 general compute (CPU) nodes and one graphical processing unit (GPU) node as well as storage appropriate for the planned usage over the lifetime of the machine. The enabled research develops along three main directions: atomistic modeling, neuroscience, and data science. Some atomistic models enabled by PRICE will study the structure and dynamics of proteins to address questions related to diseases such as Alzheimer’s. New materials modeling and design is enabled both by PRICE and by the development of new quantum simulation methods. The enabled simulations will also regard new materials design by way of genetic algorithms. The enabled neuroscience research regards computational analysis of experimental data to understand brain function, connectivity, and human behavior. Enabled data science research includes the formulation of novel cooperative artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms that will improve the outcome of machine learning (ML) models of broad applicability. In addition to enabling new science, the project realizes several societal broader impacts including broadening HPC literacy of underrepresented minorities and training the future NJ workforce using HPC in the classroom and development of new undergraduate and graduate curricula.

PRICE will comprise 60 compute nodes (52 cores/node), 700 TB of redundant storage and one GPU node (4 GPUs/node) to be housed at Rutgers University-Newark. PRICE will enable several additional research projects carried out by the PI, co-PIs, and major users at Rutgers-Newark and NJIT. The GPU portion enables state-of-the-art molecular dynamics simulations that elucidate structure and dynamics of proteins for the understanding of diseases, such as Alzheimer’s. GPUs also enable the efficient and timely execution of cooperative AI algorithms aimed at improving predictivity. The CPU nodes will enable quantum simulations aimed at materials engineering through density-functional theory calculations. These simulations facilitate the development of quantum models based on density functional theory, its subsystem formulation (which parallelizes efficiently over PRICE’s low-latency network) as well as quantum mechanical frameworks based on the exact factorization of the Schrödinger equation for multicomponent systems. CPU and GPU nodes will enable data analysis associated with neuroscience experiments aimed at uncovering how the brain modulates behavior and vision-related tasks as well as the study of neuron connectivity to understand brain function. Data from these experiments is growing exponentially due to increased instrument data flow from new fMRI units and improved technology allowing recordings of local field potentials from hundreds on neurons. The project also enables new science as well as the realization of societal broader impacts, such as broadening high-performance computing literacy of underrepresented minorities, training the future NJ workforce and recruitment of new faculty.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant enabled the acquisition, installation, and deployment of a high-performance computing (HPC) cluster, Price, housed at Rutgers University-Newark. The cluster significantly enhanced computational resources for research and teaching, benefiting Rutgers-Newark and close-by institutions. The project directly supported research in theoretical chemistry, atomic physics, neuroscience, artificial intelligence (AI), and machine learning, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and training across these fields.

 

Objectives and Accomplishments

The primary goal of the project was to provide cutting-edge computational infrastructure to advance scientific research and educational initiatives. Price has been fully operational, supporting both CPU and GPU-intensive workloads. Key accomplishments include:

 

Research Enablement: The cluster has facilitated breakthroughs in electronic structure methods, AI algorithm development, and multicomponent system modeling. It has directly supported 16 peer-reviewed journal publications, with many more indirectly benefiting from its resources.

Training and Education: Weekly online workshops have been conducted to train users at varying levels, ensuring broad accessibility to Price's capabilities. The system has been integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses, notably in Computational Chemistry, which utilized the cluster for student projects in Fall 2022 and 2024.

Technology Transfer: Price has been instrumental in supporting Quantum Click, a Rutgers-based spin-off project now part of the NSF I-Corps program. This initiative highlights the broader economic and innovation impact of the MRI-funded cluster.

Community Engagement: The cluster played a crucial role in hosting the Rutgers Summer Hackathon, where 40 participants (including students from Rutgers, NJIT, and Essex County College) learned Python programming using the cluster’s OnDemand interface. This initiative broadened computational literacy among underrepresented communities in Newark and surrounding areas.

 

Impact on Scientific Research

Price has supported computationally intensive projects in:

  • Electronic Structure and Multiscale Modeling: Advancing density embedding and machine learning methods for quantum chemistry.

  • Artificial Intelligence and Explainable AI: Developing Bayesian regression and deep learning models.

  • Neuroscience and Brain Research: Modeling brain function and cognitive networks using functional MRI and EEG data.

  • Materials Science and Drug Discovery: Predicting molecular interactions and designing new materials.

  • Computational Education and Outreach: Training students and early-career researchers in high-performance computing techniques.

Cluster Utilization and Performance

Since its deployment, Price has maintained a high utilization rate, with computational activity consistently reaching 50-70% of total capacity. The system's SLURM partitions have efficiently managed access for major users and general computing needs. This level of engagement underscores the critical demand for dedicated HPC resources in academic research.

 

Broader Impact and Future Outlook

The MRI-funded Price cluster has transformed computational research and education at Rutgers-Newark and its partner institutions. It has directly trained 30-40 students per year, supported diverse, federally funded research projects, and contributed to a growing computational ecosystem in New Jersey. The grant’s impact extends beyond academia, fostering industry partnerships and equipping students with skills relevant to the modern workforce. With the MRI grant concluding, the infrastructure established will continue to support research, training, and outreach activities. Plans are in place to sustain its operation through university support and external collaborations. The success of this initiative underscores the importance of continued investment in high-performance computing to drive scientific discovery and innovation in NJ and nationwide.
